image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from Kansas; born in Moberly, Randolph County, Mo., October 13, 1901; moved to Topeka, Kans., in 1909; attended the grade schools of Topeka, Kans., Sabetha (Kans.) High School, and Washburn College, Topeka, Kans.; LL.B., University of Chicago, 1925; was admitted to the bar in 1926 and commenced practice in Holton, Kans.; county attorney of Jackson County 1927-1931; member and president of the Holton School Board 1931-1943; member of the State senate 1941-1945; elected as a Republican to the Seventy-ninth and to the three succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1945-January 3, 1953); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1952 to the Eighty-third Congress; administrator, Housing and Home Finance Agency, Washington, D.C., from March 1953 to January 1959; vice president of Reynolds Aluminum Service Corp. 1959-1961, president, Reynolds Metals Development Corp., 1961-1967, and director 1967-1970; practiced law in Washington, D.C., from 1967 to 1990; was a resident of Washington, D.C., until his death there on June 5, 1994.

researchRecord.name: 1945-1952, 30 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The collection of Albert McDonald Cole contains general, departmental, and legislative correspondence. The general correspondence is valuable because it concerns the widest variety of contemporary issues. The departmental correspondence deals primarily with Cole's replies to constituent requests. Most of the legislative correspondence relates to pending legislation or recently passed legislation. Topics covered by the correspondence include Tuttle Creek Dam, flood control, the 1951 flood and its effects on Topeka, universal military training and veterans' benefits, housing for the poor and urban renewal, labor disputes, and the threat of global communism. A finding aid is available in the repository.
